description: CORE is an internal desktop application used by Apple advisors to log and track customer issues coming from chat, email, and phone calls. Through CORE, advisors can document customer concerns, categorize the nature of each issue, and monitor the progress of tickets from creation to resolution.
key_points: Used by advisors for issue tracking
Supports chat, email, and phone channels

description: One major feature I worked on was an AI/ML-based interaction summary feature, which was enabled for Prime users and the chat option. If the user is inactive and the chat has ended, then a summary is generated only when the chat has ended or the chat is inactive for a long time. A message is then sent to the backend, and based on the request header, we receive the summary from the backend API. Using the session ID, I displayed the summary in the IH module (Interaction History).
key_points: Triggered on chat end or long inactivity
Backend API communication using request headers

description: VIMS (Visitor Management System) is internal app used by apple, but it also supports external use cases. It is used to schedule office visits and meetings, and to manage guest access across Apple buildings. VIMS acts as a central platform for organizing workplace visits efficiently. It is a multi-platform system accessed via Web, Mobile, iPad Kiosk, and Admin Portal interfaces, all of which share a single backend to ensure consistent data and access control.
key_points: Manages office visits and guest access
Supports both internal and external users

description: Feature-wise, I worked on visit scheduling with custom dates, location-based UI behavior, and notification-related flows. Most of my work involved handling complex UI state, reflecting backend validations clearly, and building reusable components like shared tables and tokenizer search to support these features across the application.

One challenging situation I faced was making a search component fully accessible. At that time, I wasn't very familiar with accessibility, especially VoiceOver behavior. The component had dynamic suggestions, keyboard navigation, search and multi-select options, so making it accessible wasn't simple. I spent time understanding screen readers, collaborated with the accessibility team, added proper ARIA attributes, fixed tab order, and ensured correct focus movement. The component passed accessibility checks and gave me hands-on accessibility experience.

BDD (Behavior-Driven Development) describes the expected behavior of an application in plain language. It focuses on what the application should do rather than how it is implemented. Cucumber is commonly used for BDD.

I approach performance from three angles: build time, runtime, and monitoring. At build time, I reduce bundle size using code splitting, lazy loading, and tree shaking. At runtime, I avoid unnecessary re-renders and optimize API usage. For monitoring, I use DevTools and production monitoring tools.

To handle cybersecurity in an application, I validate and sanitize inputs, implement secure authentication and role-based access, enforce HTTPS, encrypt sensitive data, prevent common attacks like XSS and CSRF, and use logging and monitoring to detect unusual activities.
